author: linux_mclinuxface@fosstodon.org
content:
@alexblock @crcordray :sigh: no.

3D printed homes are, at best, a niche idea and, at worst, a grift. In Canada? Grift.

What 3D printing replaces is not super expensive nor complicated (framing/cladding) yet it introduces a whole raft of problems and complexities.

What you end up with is pretty close to a concrete (cinder) block house. Have you lived in one of these? I have it. It's miserable in even mild climates, much less Canada. Why? Thermal bridging.

1/2

author: linux_mclinuxface@fosstodon.org
content:
@alexblock @crcordray

Take this example from the nidus3d page. See the part I've outlined in red?

The outside is directly connected to the inside walls. The wall will try to reach equilibrium bringing the cold _inside_ your house and your heating _outside_ your house (+ condensation problems).

Quality homes in cold climates go to great lengths to thermally isolate inside and outside (3x pane windows, thermal breaks, special membranes, etc.).

There are many other problems too.

2/2

author: davep@infosec.exchange
content:
@linux_mclinuxface @alexblock @crcordray Structural straw bale has great thermal efficiency. Coupled with lime render (on the outside) and clay/lime render (on the inside, for high thermal mass) it's a solution that doesn't require membranes and allows water vapour to pass through.

It can also be coupled with a passive solar design. But you need to get the fitting just right unless it's as a separate sun room.

author: linux_mclinuxface@fosstodon.org
content:
@davep @alexblock @crcordray there are lots of alternate methods of construction that have big advantages that need to be more broadly explored. They just aren‚Äôt as sexy as squirting concrete with a giant robot.

(Ive been very interested in double walled rammed earth, personally.)

author: tal@mastodon.social
content: @linux_mclinuxface they look disconnected to me (apart from at window sides), what am I missing?

author: linux_mclinuxface@fosstodon.org
content:
@tal everything is connected. They are continuous loops of concrete.

It‚Äôs just easy to see at the window penetrations.

author: tal@mastodon.social
content: @linux_mclinuxface I understand the loops, but I can't see how outside is thermally connected to inside - there seems to be a continuous clear air-gap from outer face to the wavy middle wall. I can see a connection from the middle to the inner wall alright.

author: linux_mclinuxface@fosstodon.org
content:
@tal the air gap is a distraction in this case.

okay: imagine you have a line of concrete. One end of the line has a 100c heat source and an ambient temperature of 20c. Will the other end of the line get warm after time? Sure it will. (Doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs -100c or +100c)

Concrete is basically a conductor with an r value of 0.1 per 1‚Äù vs even basic insulators are ~30x better. Anything that breaks the material will be better than a loop of one material.

author: rayckeith@techhub.social
content:
@andyw350

it turns out rationing in our multiple-payer system is worse because an individual person only has one payer: their insurance.

the pool of participating doctors in a single health insurance plan is much smaller than if it were national one-payer plan like canada. the smaller pool in a typical USA health insurance plan means more rationing.

I'm excluding very rich people, who effectively have the whole world as their pool of participating doctors.

the belief that people in Canada wait more than in the USA is a myth.

author: gkmizuno@mas.to
content:
Then, there's the question of, were you to be able to cut out a section of a floor plate ~ 7' x 14', would that afford you extra housing units?

No.

You're just increasing the "rentable" area, such that one extra bedroom can be added onto one unit. That's it.

There are far more effective means to rapidly increase housing:

a) cap property taxes on ADUs in areas w/ high tax rates;
b) eliminate low density zoning;
c) use "tax increment financing" to pay for infrastructure instead of SDCs.

author: gkmizuno@mas.to
content:
Does a single stair design make it more economical to maximize housing? The numbers they cite are...fantastical. Sure, on smaller structures, it can save *as much as* 10%.

But at the scale most affordable residential structures are, it's a drop in the bucket.

And they don't appear to understand that other parts of the ICC would still require a stairway exceedingly wider than a normal stairs, such that you would certainly prefer to create two separate stairs than one that is 6' wide.
#Housing

author: Grovewest@sfba.social
content: @gkmizuno The deregulation issue is about contractors who want to nickle and dime customers with marginal construction design and materials in order to maximise profit and decrease labor. Not about resident safety, durability or affordability. The industry needs a disruptor - competition in the trades that is capable of doing a relatively quality job at affordable prices.

content: @Grovewest That's exactly what I think, too.

@ideogram actually, 11, and a twelfth is programed.

author: oook@im-in.space
content:
@tredok @ideogram my father was not in military but I have had similar experience being also in my mid forties with 14 moves.

I think having moved a lot as a kid made me different than people of my age who grew up in the same place. I have been used to lose and recreate fragile and low stake friendships on a regular basis. It makes it easier to move as an adult but you tend to take friendships, community and social interactions less seriously because you learnt as a kid that braking important relationships is hard. Home is wherever I am at that moment in time.

Whenever I meet people I appreciate I rarely ask for said people phone numbers. It keeps surprising my partner. Usually people end up reaching for me through her or relatives because I haven't had the reflex of exchanging contact. And I am rarely the one doing the first step in that direction. I just don't even think about it. It is some sort of social clumsiness, I like having a laugh with people but I don't make relationships grow.

The proposal says that the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program [#LIHEAP] is ‚Äúunnecessary‚Äù because Trump is planning to increase domestic #oil & #gas production & reduce #energy prices. Last month, the admin fired everyone working in the program‚Äôs office, which currently helps 6.2 million Americans nationwide offset high #UtilityBills.

#economy

author: Nonilex@masto.ai
content:
#Trump is proposing a >$4.5B cut to the #Agriculture Dept, about a 17% trim from its #budget for fiscal year 2025. Programs facing the steepest cuts include #farm conservation programs & #rural development that the admin argues is redundant & #research that it characterizes as ‚Äúwoke.‚Äù

The budget includes a $15M increase for #food inspection, but interestingly does not include cuts to #FoodStamps ‚Äîwhich will likely be a point of contention in #Congress.

#farmers #farming #economy

content:

But one corner of the education budget he would boost: #CharterSchools [I wonder if this has something to do w/the #religious charter school case before #SCOTUS right now]. His budget proposal would increase federal support for new charter schools by $60 million, or about 8.3%.

#law #education #Constitution #ChurchAndState

#GeographicEquity #law #science

content: #ElonMusk & #SpaceX are big winners in #Trump‚Äôs #budget. 1st, Trump wants to put ‚Äúa down-payment on the development & deployment of a ‚Äò#GoldenDome‚Äô‚Ä¶, a next-generation missile defense shield‚Äù that SpaceX is going to play a major role in building. #law #racism #EthnicCleansing

content:

author: Nonilex@masto.ai
content:

#law #GunViolence #GunControl #regulations

content:
#Trump is planning to eliminate the National Center for Complementary & Integrative Health [#NCCIH], saving $170M. This is the center at #NIH charged w/examining whether supplements & other alternative medical treatments are helpful or dangerous.

#SAMHSA was established in 1992, not under #Biden.

author: Nonilex@masto.ai
content: In announcing $18B in cuts to #NIH, the #Trump admin said the #health agency ‚Äúpromoted radical gender ideology to the detriment of America‚Äôs youth.‚Äù It cited a study of #transgender youth that measured their psychological & social well-being 2 yrs after they had been prescribed hormone treatments. author: Nonilex@masto.ai

author: Nonilex@masto.ai
content:

All programs supported by the #NSF concerning #DEI in the sciences are to be eliminated. But funding for #AI & #quantum information science is to remain the same.

author: Nonilex@masto.ai
content: Per the NYT & Center for American Progress, #Trump‚Äôs #budget would cut nondefense programs to their LOWEST LEVEL IN THE MODERN ERA (these records only go back to the 1960s). @Alpha1Nine I'd rather see a focus on making PT better than a focus on the price. Mostly people complain about poor access/reliability, price is definitely a less.important concern. And there's a direct correlation between good PT infra and $$$ housing, so making it free/cheap advantages people living in established areas or that can at least afford.to move to where the PT is.

#PublicTransport

author: trib
content:
@jedsetter @Alpha1Nine sure, but a federal party has no direct influence on public transport quality; it's mostly a local government issue, with a little bit of state thrown in for good measure, and heavily influenced by whether the local government contracts a provider or pays for its own PT provision.

I'm even dubious about how a federal government, or influencing party, would drive change to fares at a local level? Do they shovel earmarked money at local councils? Reading the policy, it's about influencing.

I'm a Greens member, and heavily involved (even running a booth tomorrow), and I think this policy is more noise than anything else.

All that said, PT should be free at point of use. It's a huge socioeconomic lift when it is and opens up access to work in places people who have to live in exurbs might not otherwise be able to get to (see also housing, 15 minute cities, and the fact that people shouldn't have to commute vast time/distance to get to work).

author: jedsetter
content: @trib @Alpha1Nine 100% it's out of scope really for federal politics. but what a party chooses to say or have as policies tells us who they are and what they stand for. I'd prefer the greens stand for better PT than cheaper PT. and yes it could be a por que no Los dos but I keep seeing reference to this free fare thing and not much around service or infra.

Take care #voting, make your #Preferences count. ‚ö†Ô∏è

‚ÄúPreferences have become more important than ever in Australian elections, as the share of people supporting the major parties has dropped from more than 90% of primary votes in the 1950s to just 68.8% in the most recent federal poll.

The last Australian election saw 16 seats won by candidates who were not leading after the first count ‚Äì the most ever, tied with 2016. And more than half of those winners were independent candidates ‚Äì also the most ever.

Australia‚Äôs electoral system requires #voters to #number #candidates in their order of preference: their first choice, second choice and so on. During #counting, if no candidate has yet achieved a #majority, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated and their votes are redistributed to voters‚Äô next #preference. This is repeated until there is a clear winner.‚Äù

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Interestingly we have already spent 60% of the $100 million affordable housing spend planned over ten years. Looking back, that was wise given the recent shortage of funds to reduce costs in the United States. I personally remain hopeful that we will see some of those funds restored in the future.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: The main two pain points have been adequately funding administrative costs and meeting the needs of families making under 30% of Area Median Income, which are the families most in need of support and also the most costly to address because the financial gaps are so wide there.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Councilor Payne noting the dramatic cost and inflation changes since the $100 million target was established in 2019

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Part of the rise in admin costs will be due to the need to physically inspect homes as they increasingly are built and occupied

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Councilor Pinkston noting how essential it has been to have strong partnerships with local housing nonprofits to be able to act fast and solve large, expensive problems as they have jumped up, often with very little notice.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Some disagreement among Councilors about whether housing funds from Inclusionary Zoning should count against the $100 million funding goal. We have two large projects underway with very large dollar figures attached.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Mayor Wade noting incredible progress on what we know about what we are doing over his last three years of public service. (YES)

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Some anxiety on Council about whether vital federal Section 8 housing funds will be cut. We don't know yet. https://www.housingwire.com/articles/trump-administration-eyes-deep-cuts-to-section-8-low-income-housing-vouchers/

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Turning to #LandBank ordinance. This is something we have been talking about as a solution for many years. I personally am a big fan. Our City Manager has personal experience with this tool, which gives me great confidence.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: In the draft schedule, I see a functioning land bank summer 2026, if approved. That is light speed by government standards.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: Reportedly there are foundations that are interested in supporting this effort, which would dramatically speed up the efficacy of getting land cleaned up and ready for safe and affordable housing. We had been assuming we would be 100% on the hook for this.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: I have to stop livetooting for now, but the whole thing should be posted on Youtube soon and I expect that Sean Tubbs will have an article out on this in the next couple of days.

author: Lyle@cville.online
content: There is some additional info here https://communityengagement.substack.com/p/week-ahead-for-april-21-2025-albemarle
